ta'us.
did.

If I am correct in attributing the pluperfect meaning to the termina-
ti, the word tiristi should signify "they [or he] had called," but
the sense appears to be passive here; the lost word, meaning "tribute," may be vannam, as in vi. 14, but I do not quite understand that passage, nor am I sure about the correct division of the words. Anu, is perhaps "day;" we find the equivalent of "heaven" and "God," with the initial or determinative \(>\) \(>\), and it is probable that "the day" would have such a distinction; we certainly find it whenever the day of the month is named, and it always precedes the monogram signifying "month," as well as the name of the month. I conclude therefore that it is suggestive of all words having a cosmical or celestial meaning.

I. 8. hiak Tariyavans Ko nanri:—Tahiyaus ye ativa, Yoṣ-irra and Darius king says:— provinces these in, the man [ariki ṭartuka,] yufri ir kuṭkti; [Yoṣ-irra arikkas,] yufri pious, in retribution he him I cherished; the man who was impious, him ṭartuka vial ea........... sauvin Auramasta-na .............nīna, in retribution greatly I punished; by favour of Ormazd Tahiyaus Hu-nĪna kuktak; appo anka Hu-ikki-mar tirikka, provinces of me cherished; what if by me was told, yuvenpa yuttas. that they did.

From the analogy of kuktak, l. 19, kuktas, III. 85, and kuktaiinti, III. 86, I should have made the equivalent of "I cherished," kuktayos, for the impression is barely visible; but in III. 81, kuktis is perfectly distinct; for ṭartuka, see III. 64. I cannot venture to restore the lost passages. Anka may generally be translated "if," but joined to appo the word "whatsoever" will usually represent the sense most conveniently.

I. 9. hiak Tariyavans Ko nanri:—Auramasta ye Kovas Hu and Darius king said:— Ormazd this kingdom to me ṭunis; hiak Auramasta pikti Hu-tūa, kus Hu Kovas ye "patu, gave; and Ormazd helper to me was, while I kingdom this gained, hiak sauvin Auramasta-na Hu Kovas marriya. and by favour of Ormazd I kingdom possessed.

Patu is not clear on the impression, but the termination is probable; the word would bo put for patuva, like afpi for affiya. The restorations are obvious.

I. 10. hiak Tariyavans Ko nanri:—ye appo Hu "yuuttas, and Darius king says:— this [is] what I did,
BEHISTUN INSCRIPTION.

saunin Auramasta-na, thap appo Ko-oas [or Ko-ra] tuwa:
by favour of Ormazd, when that king I became:
Kanpuchiya yesi, Kuras sakri, Nikapi Nivans, yufri nen am ...........
Cambyses called, Cyrus' son, our race, before
hiak hika, Kanpuchiya yufri Bartiya ir afpis; thap Kanpuchiya
? Cambyses he Bardes him killed; when Cambyses
Bartiya ir afpis, Tassunos inni tarnas appo Bartiya afpika; vasni
Bardes him killed, the people not knew that Bardes was killed; then
Kanpuchiya Mutšariya-fa-ikki poris; vasni Tassunos arikkas,
Cambyses to Egypt went; then the people became wicked,
kutta titkimas Tahiyaus-ativa irsikki yuttas, kutta Parsan-ikki,
and falsehood provinces in greatly was, both in Persia,
kutta Mata-pa-ikki, hiak kutta Tahiyaus appo tahie-ativa,
and in Media, and also provinces the others in.

In l. 22 I have restored saunin Auramasta-na, the space being
just sufficient, and the last two letters visible, though the expression is
not found in the Persian; the space following is too large for ṣṣṣ only, but the word concluding with ṣṣṣ must be ṣṣṣ ṣṣṣ. The
expression is quite different from that of the fifteenth Paragraph,
although, oddly enough for the sense of the inscription, both the Baby-
lonian and the corrected Persian (see Notes, p. ii) concur in reading
"after I became king," in both cases. The few letters lost at the
beginning of l. 23 comprise all that there could have been to represent
the Persian lines 29 and 30, of which the translation is "he was king
here before me; the brother of this Cambyses was named Bardes; he
was of the same father and mother with Cambyses." The phrase in
l. 24, "the people knew not that Bardes was slain," corrects the first
translation given by Colonel Rawlinson, and ascertains the value of
the Persian word azada, which, here at least, must mean "unknown."
In a very difficult passage of the Naksh-i-Rustam Inscription, this
word occurs twice, and the certainty of its meaning here may help
us in finding the sense of that passage. Arikkas, in l. 24, is restored
doubtfully from the analogy of arikka am, in III. 79.

I. 11. hiak vasni Buven kir Makus, "Gaumatta yesi, yufri
and then man one Magian, Gomates named, he
...nasá ...... Karaś Arakkatarris yesi, avi ivaka, XIV annan
issischadis in mountain Aracadres named, there he arose, on the 14th day
annons an-vikanna-s-na pirka, yechitu ivaka; yufri Tassunos Apir
of the month Viyakhna then, thus he arose; he to people (?)
tiraska nanri:—Hu Bartiya, Kuras sakri, Kanpuchiya i……… ears; lying said:— I Bardes, Cyrus’ son, Cambyses’ brother am; vasi Tassunos varrita Kanpuchiya-ikki-mar pafati fa, yufrikki po ris, then people all from Cambyses revolting, to him went, kutta Parsan, hiak kutta Mata-pa, hiak kutta Tahiyaus appo tahie; both Persis, and also Media, and also provinces the others; Kovas yufri marris; IX annan anmonan garvapata na pirka, kingdom he seized; on the 9th day of the month Garmapada then, yechitu Kanpuchiya ………… hiak vasi Kanpu chiya aspi pa …… su thus Cambyses …………… and then Cambyses killing himself(?). aspik.

There is not space in the l. 27 for the word Pissiachadia, which we should expect to find, and the characters preserved will not enter into such a name. Aracdris is quite distinct, as well as kuras, “a mountain;” (Wotia gurez): both are preceded by — meaning “at.” In the dates I divide annan from the following syllables, and attribute to it the signification of “day,” because the group annan is omitted in II. 47, and the usually corresponding Persian word rauchabish is also omitted in the text, II. 61; for a similar reason pirka must represent the Persian thakata aka, whatever that phrase may import; the Scythic — is certainly the Babylonian —, and I am unable to say why it is always accompanied by the additional syllables. I join the an to the name of the month, because we have the same syllable added to other words expressing periods of time and the like, (see l. 16, ante). In l. 28 the word apr cannot be the dative postposition, though one is wanted there, because such a particle would never be preceded by Y, or as we should say, be written with a capital letter; in l. 60, where the word appir occurs in a somewhat similar connection, differing slightly in spelling only, we have the usual postposition pa after Tassunos; in the latter instance the word has not the Y, though space seems to have been left for it. The faint traces of the word meaning “brother” in l. 29 look like —; I should like to read them — uk, cognate with the Zyrianian rok, “a brother.” The lost word after Kanpuchiya, in l. 31, may have been erius, but the phrase is not in the Persian; we find there only the repetition of the preceding words, “he seized the kingdom.” In l. 32 nothing is quite distinct but the passive aspik,
"he was killed." We may here remark that this paragraph does not commence with the usual formula "Darius the king says." By-and-bye we shall find several of the shorter paragraphs in the same case, especially towards the close of the Inscription.

I. 12. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Kovas yupa appo Gaumatšta and Darius king says:—kingdom that which Gomates akka Makus Kanpuchiya eviťusti, Kovas am neni karata turi the Magian Cambyes had deprived, kingdom former time from Nivanš Nikavi tàs; vasnī Gaumatšta akka Makus Kanpuchiya family our was; then Gomates the Magian Cambyeses eviťus, kutta Parsan, hiak kutta Mata-pa, hiak kutšta Tahiyaus deprived, both Persia, and also Media, and also provinces appo tahie, yufri eviťusa tuvan e, yufri Kovas yupipa-na morris. the others, he having seized, (?) he kingdom of them held.

The restorations in lines 32 and 33 are obvious, and the construction of the whole paragraph is easy, with the exception of the few words near the close, which I cannot understand. The last letter is certainly, and the preceding letter is probably; there is just room for yupipa-na, "of them." The horizontal wedge, meaning "in" or "with," may have preceded Nivanš in l. 33.

I. 13. *hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Yoş-irra-inna senrik innī and Darius king says:—of the men there was not Ruven kir Parsarra, inšnī Mata, hiak innī Nivanš Nikavi, akka man one Persian, nor Mede, and not family our, who Gaumatšta Makus Kovas eviťus; Tassunos-vas .......... maši; Gomates Magian kingdom would deprive; the State feared him; Tassunos irsikki afsip Akkapu sašsa Bartiya ir tarnasti, he people utterly he killed who the former Bardes him had known, ṭupainraskimmas Tassunos irsiškki afsip, hini Hu ir tarnampi therefore the people utterly he killed, let not me it make known ppo Hu innī Bartiya akka Kuras Sakri; hiak Akkari afsi ṭat I not Bardes who Cyrus' son; and every one move(?) Gaumatšta Makus thubaka innī lulwak, kus Hu šinnigat; vasnī Gomates Magian about(?) not dared, until I came; then In Auramasta astiyaivanyahi, Auramasta pikti Hu-tās, šanvin I Ormazd adored, Ormazd helper to me was, by favour
Auramasta-na, X annan amnong an-bagayatis-na "pirka, yechitu Yoṣ of Ormazd, 10th day of the month of Bagayadish then, thus men ariki-fa itaka, Hu Gaumata akka Makus ir afpiya, kutta "Yoṣ faithful with, I Gomates the Magian him killed, and men appo atarrivan nitavi yupo-fa pi itaka, > Yuvanis > Siktukvatis yesi who followers his chiefs who with, at a fort at Sietaehotes named > Nissaya "yesi, > Tahiyahus Mata-pa-ikki, avi ir afpiya, Kovas at Nissea named, at province in Media, there him I killed, kingdom Hu evituca, sauvia Auramasta-na "Hu Kovas yutta, Auramasta I took away, by favour of Ormazd I king was, 'Ormaad Kovas Hu tunis.

The analysis of this paragraph is pretty clear, where the text is not deficient. The clause beginning l. 38, which appeared doubtful in the Persian, is here consistent and probable: "he utterly destroyed the people who had been acquainted with the former Bardes; and the reason why he destroyed them was 'that they may not make it known (said he) that I am not Bardes, the son of Cyrus.'" The form tarnampi occurs in no other passage, but it should be a causative; the letter preceding pi is imperfect, but hardly doubtful. May the construction be hini Hu ir tarnam-pi, "let me not make it known to any, that," &c. the tarnam recovering the usual Ugrian m in the first person singular before pi, which is dropped when final? The necessity for making the verb causative is against this construction, to say nothing of the useless pi. If we might read tarnaspi, it would be "lest there be any who may know me," though even then we do not know what to do with r. With the exception of the clause immediately following, where aški, thubaka, and luwak are of uncertain import, all the rest is perfectly clear.

I. 14. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Kovas appo Nirvan and Darius king says:—kingdom which family Nikavi ikkimar kutkaturrakki, yupa Hu nogaya; Hu > Kaṭe-os our from was taken away, that I brought [back]; I in place passankita; thap appo "anka appuka-ta, yechitu ....... Hu anchiyam established; as what if before soever, thus I did; I visitation annappatna yutta appo Gaumata akka Makus "charista, hiak Hu Temples of Gods made which Gomates the Magian abolished, and I Tassunoe-na chotàs hiak aé, hiak Kartas, hiak > Alyeṣ-pe ....chiva the people's .................... and ........... and to the families ...........
appi lu........ya appo Gaumatta akka Makus ev-ap-tusta; hiak Hu those I restored which Gomates the Magian took from them; and I Tassunos Kaṭa-va passankita, kutuṭa Parsan, hiak kutta Mata-pa, the people in place established, both Persia, and also Media, hiak kutta Tahiyahu appo tahie .... .......ta, yechitu, thap ṣappo anka and also provinces the others thus, as what if appuka-ta, Hu appo kutkaturrakki, yupa nogaya; sauvin before soever, I what was taken away, that I brought back; by favour Auramasta-na, ye Hu yutṣta, Hu baluikvasga .... kus Alyeṣ Nikavi of Ormazd, this I did, I laboured (?) until family our Kaṭa-va passankita, yechitu thap appuka-ta; hiṣṣak Hu baluikvasga in place I established, thus as before soever; and I laboured (?) .... sauvin Auramasta-na appo Gaumatta akka Makus Alyeṣ Nikavi by favour of Ormazd that Gomates the Magian family our ṣinni kutkatur ....... not might destroy.

Though the import of this paragraph is generally pretty clear, I am utterly unable to see my way grammatically through several clauses, either in the Persian or Scythic text; the Babylonian affords no further help than merely shewing that anchiyan annappatna means “temples of the gods;” or at least includes that phrase: it is known from other sources, that annop signifies “the gods.” See also the Artaxerxes Inscription. The phrase Kaṭava passankita represents gāthwā avātāyam, and it seems to prove that gāthwā cannot be equivalent to an adverb like “firmly,” because it is transcribed and not translated, and is preceded by the mark -. A comparison with the root ātkā induces me to render kaṭa by “place,” and to make a the usual locative postposition. Near end of l. 52, thap may be nka; the first character is invisible, the second may be -.

I. 15. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:-ye appo Hu-ikki-mar and Darius king says:- this what by me uttak, thap appo anka appuka Kovas marriya. as done, when that if before kingdom I seized.

The expression thap appo anka appuka, is the same as that which represents “as it was anciently” in the preceding paragraph; the indefinite ta alone, represented by the Persian chiya, being added in the former case; the general sense of the inscription shows that the meaning must be “when first I seized the kingdom,” but I confess I
should have understood the words to mean "before I seized the kingdom."

I. 16. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—thap Gaumāṣṭa akka
and Darius king says:— when Gomates the
Makus Hu afpiya, vasnī Assina yesi, Afartīśra, Ukbaṭarranna
Magian I killed, then Atrines named, a Susian, Upadarma's
Sakri, "yufri Afartīkki ivaka nanri: Ko-vas Afartī-pa Hu yutta-vara;
son, he in Susiana rising said: king to Susiana I am;
vasnī Afartī-fa Huikki-mar pafati-fa-ba, Assina yufrikka poris;
then Susians from me revolting, to Atrines went;
vasnī Ko-vas yufri Afartī-fa-na yuttās; hiak kutta Ruven kir
then king he of the Susians became; and also man one
Nititpaal yesi, Bapilurra, Ahinahira Saikri, yufri —Bapilu ivaka,
Natitabirus named, a Babylonian, Ænsera's son, he in Babylon rising,
Tassunos-pa yechitu appir tiraska nanri: Hu Nabukutarraśar, tar
to the people thus them lying said: I Nabuchodrossor, son
nabpunīta vara; vasnī Tassunos appo Bapilu-fa varrita
of Nabonidus am; then people the Babylonians all
Nititpaal yufrikki poris; vasnī Bapilu-fa pafatifa, Kovas appo
to Natitabirus went; then Babylonians revolting, kingdom which
Bapilu-fa-pa yufri marris.
to the Babylonians he possessed.

The above paragraph barely requires a word of comment. The
distinction between Afartī "Susiana," Afartī "the Susians," and
Afartu (last syllable doubtful) "a Susian," is well seen. With regard
to appir in l. 60, see Par. XI., l. 28.

I. 17. hiak ṣTariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasnī Hu yutro
and Darius king said:— then I a messenger(?)
Afartikki nogaya, Assina yufri marrika, rabbaka, Hu-ikki nogaik;
to Susians sent, Atrines he taken, bound, to me was brought;
vasnī Hu ir afpiya.
then I him killed.

Yutro is certainly allied to yuttu "son." This paragraph exem-
plifies the use of the final vowel in marrika and rabbaka.

I. 18. hiak Tariyavaus Ko naṇnri:—vasnī Hu Bapilu poriya,
and Darius king says:— then I Babylon went,
Nititpaal yufrikka akka nanri, Hu Nabukutarrusar; *Tassunos to Natitabirus who says, I [am] Nabuchodrossor; army appo Nititpaal yufri-na, Hiş Tikra yesi, avi pathafati, Tikra which of Natitabirus, at river Tigris named, there had arrived(?), Tigris Seurišt marris, kutta... taven. t heşna; vasi Hu Tassunos-vas shores(?) held, and sent ships(?); then I the army kamas... nika appo poke hiapvaş-va appin patu... po on boats placed(?) which enemy in difficulty(?) them I placed(?)
poke karraş ir pafalufaba, Auramasta pikti Hu-tas, sauvin enemy? him having attacked(?), Ormazd helper to me was, by favour Auramasta-na Tikra antugshutta, avi Tassunos appo Nititpaal yufri-na of Ormazd Tigris we crossed, there army which of Natitabirus afpiya; XXVI annan anmonş an-assiyatiyas-na pirka, yechitu I destroyed; 26th day of the month of Atriya then, thus saprakimmas yuttayun'i, ir...... avi afpi.
the battle we fought, him there I slew.

From l. 66 to 68 the construction is obscure, and some characters occur which are not found elsewhere. This, combined with the mutilation of both the Persian and Scythic texts, prevents my attempting an explanation; all the rest is clear. Observe the expression "a river called Tigris," as though written by a people to whom the river was unknown. The clause at the end, "I slew him there," is not found in the Persian; and from the omission of the termination ya, and the way in which the lines are inscribed on the rock, it looks as though the engraver considered the following word, which begins a new paragraph, to be merely a continuation of the same clause.

I. 19. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasi Hu Bapilu poriya; and Darius king says:—then I Babylon went; *batar Bapilu inbalu-va pugatta, Afş Šatşan yesi, Ḥufarata when(?) Babylon town(?) in I arrived, town Zazan named, Euphrates satavatak avvi Nititpaal yufri akka nanri, Hu Nabukutarrusar, along(?) there Natitabirus he who said, I [am] Nabuchodrossor, Tassunos itaka, Hu rutās şi'nnik, saprakimmas yuttivanra; vasi people with, me against came, the battle about to fight; then saprakimmas yuttayut, Auramasta pikti Hu-tas, sauvin the battle we fought, Ormazd helper to me was, by favour Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Nititpaal yufri-na avi afpiya; II annan of Ormazd people who of Natitabirus there I killed; 2nd day
anmonš "an-anavakkas-na pırks, yechitu saprakimmas yuttaynt,
of month Anamaka then, thus the battle we fought,
Tassunos appo Nititpaal-na Hu afpi irsik"ki, hiak apin hiş-va
people who of Natitabirus I destroyed utterly, and them in river
puttans, hiş ye-va sathak.
I drove, river in this were drowned. (?)

Several words at the beginning of this paragraph are not found
elsewhere:—batar, inbaluva, pugatta, satavatak, rutàs; all these are
of course rendered conjecturally only. The name of the Enphrates is
very faint, but I think the first three syllables are certain. The last
clause is obscure. It will be noticed that the Scythic version has
transposed the closing sentences of this paragraph.

II. 1.* hiak Tariyaus Ko nanri:—vasnī "Nititpaal yufri
and Darius king says:—then Natitabirus he
Talni-fa ariki-fa itaka putraska, . . . Bapilu lufaba; vasnī Hu
horsemen faithful with marching, to Babylon retiring; then I
"Bapilu-ikki pugatta; şauvin Anramasta-na, kutta Bapilu
to Babylon approached; by favour of Ormazd, and Babylon
mariya, kutta Nititpaal yufri pinti; vasnī Nititpaal yufri Hu
I took, and Natitabirus . . .; then Natitabirus I
Bapilu ir afsiya.
in Babylon him killed.

The name of Darius in the first line of this paragraph is incorrectly
engraved. I cannot restore the word which precedes Bapilu in l. 78;
there is room for batar, as in l. 72, but I do not know its meaning;
the word following is very doubtful. The other restorations are
probable. The horizontal — before Babylon, in l. 79, is the only one
I remember in all the inscription, before the name of a place, which
does not effect the meaning of “at” or “in.” The word at the
beginning of l. 80, which I have very doubtfully made pinti, may
be the usual mariya; the paper impression shews only undecided
traces. The hiak in outline at the end of the lithographed facsimile,
is inserted from the supposition that this column closed in the same
way as the second. The paper cast towards the close is so much
mutilated that it is not possible to say whether this was the case or
not.

* We now come to the part which corresponds with the second Persian
column.
COLUMN II.

We now come to the second Scythic column, corresponding with nearly all the second and part of the third Persian columns. This portion of the inscription is almost perfect; scarcely a single letter is illegible or doubtful. It happens unfortunately that this is the column which contains all those statements of marches and fights, which abound in repetitions; and these are so precisely alike in all their clauses, that they might be restored in most cases with absolute confidence, however mutilated the text might be. It is impossible to avoid a feeling of regret that it is the second and not the third column which is so well preserved: there are so many varied constructions in the closing paragraphs of the inscription, including the different persons and tenses and moods of the several verbs used, that a complete Scythic version there would have given a much deeper insight into the structure of the language than we are now likely to attain. But that column is deplorably damaged; and the Persian text also is most defective in the part corresponding to it. The second column, which we are about to enter upon, is free from this cause of uncertainty, and we have no other difficulty than ignorance of the language.

II. 2. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—kus Hu > Bapilu sennigat,
and i Darius king says:—whilst I in Babylon was,
appi Tahiyau's Hu ir-pafatifa; Parsan, hiak Afarti, hiak Mata-pa,
these provinces against me rebelled; Peris, and Susiana, and the Medes,
hiak Aásura, hiak Mu'tsariya-fa, hiak Parthuva-fa, hiak Markus-pa,
and Assyria, and the Egyptians, and Parthians, and Margians,
hiak Thattakus, hiak Sak'ka-pa,
and Sattagydia, and the Sacae.

In the expression Hu ir-pafatifa, the letter r is added rather to the second word than to the first, because the termination fa is apparently participial without such addition, as in lines 7 and 11,* and because Huir, as a case-form of Hu, is not found elsewhere; unless the clause in I. 39 should be so construed.

II. 3. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Ruven kir Martiya yesi,
and Darius king says:—man one Martius named,

* A paragraph mentioning the frequent participial signification of neuter verbs terminating in ks and fa, such as ivaka and pafatifa, when unaccompanied by the pronoun ir, was inadvertently omitted in p. 88.
Issan'şakris Sakri, Afş Kukkannakan yesi, Parsan-ikki, avi Sisicir's son, in a town Cyganaca named, in Persia, there artak; yufri A'fartikki ivaka, Tassunos-pa yechitu ap-tiriz, he dwelled; he in Susiana rising, to the people thus them addressed, nanri:—Hu Immannis Ko Afarti-na va'ra; he said:—I Imanes king of Susiana am;

II. 4. hiak Hu avasir Affarti inkanna sennigat, vasni Affarti-fa and I when Susians friendly(?) was, then Susians Hu-ikki-mar fanifa, Martiya yufri akka irsarra appinI by me influenced(?), Martius he whom leader appointed tiristi, ir marrisaa, ir afpis. they had named, him seizing, him they killed.

The word avasir in l. 7 is made a conjunction, because followed by sennigat, a verbal form generally found after a conjunction; and the Persian equivalent adakiya may be allied to ṣaṣṣa; the ṣ as a component part of the word is probably connected with the same syllable in vasni “then,” and vasiesin “after.” The fourth paragraph, like the eleventh of Column I., begins without the usual formula; we shall find this occur frequently. The word which I have read fanifa may be tanifa, as in vi. 14.

II. 5. hiak Ta'riyavaus Ko nanri:—Ruvem kir, Fruvaris and Darius king says:—man one, Phraortes yesi, yufri Mata-pa-ikki ivaka, Tassunos-pa yechitu ap-tirissa named, he among the Medians rising, to people thus addressing them nanri:—Hu Satarrita, Nimanş Vakstarra-na nima"aki vara; vasni said:—I Xathrites, family of Cyaxares descended am; then Tassunos Mata-pa appo Hu remanni, yupipa Hu-ikki-mar people Medians who with me at home, they from me pafatifa, yu'frikki poris; Mata-pa-ikki Ko-vas yufri yuttas. revolting, to him went; in Media king he became.

Nivanki is probably connected with Nivans, notwithstanding the difference of the first syllable; the root nem, “to generate,” still exists in Magyar. I have no clue to the etymology of remanni, the first syllable being an unknown sound, and the Persian text lost; but the Babylonian version here, and a comparison of this passage with a corresponding one in III. 3, where the Persian text is clear, shew a connection with “house” or “home.” Observe the locative ṣ before Hu, meaning “with me.”
II. 6. Tassunos Parsan hiak Mata-pa Hu-ta\textsuperscript{18}e, arikki senri; People Persian and Medes to me were, faithful they were; vasi Hu Tassunos Mata-pa-ikki tifapa tavon; Vitarna yesi, then I people to the Medians envoys sent; Hydarnes named, Parsar kir, Hu\textsuperscript{14}Lubaruri, yufri Irsarra appiu ir yutta; yechitu Persian one, my subject, him leader appointed him I made; thus ap-tiriya: vitas, Tassunos Ma\textsuperscript{16}ta-pa akka-pa Hu-nina inni to them I said: go, people Medes who of me not tirivan pi, yupi-pa afpis vanka: vasi Vitarna Tassunos itaka are named who, them slay? then Hydarnes people with Mata-pa\textsuperscript{14}ikki thak; thap Mata-pa-ikki ir-porik, Af\textsuperscript{15} Marus to Media went; when to Media he went, at a town Marus yesi, Mata-pa-ikki, avi saprak\textsuperscript{17}immas yuttas; akka named, in Media, there the battle they fought; he who Mata-pa-na irsarra avasir inni arir, Auramasta pikti Hu-ta\textsuperscript{18}e, of the Medians [was] leader when not? Ormazd helper to me was, sauvin Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Hu-nina Tassunos appo by favour of Ormazd people which mine People which Patifa-na irsikki afpis; XX\textsuperscript{19}VII annan anmon\textsuperscript{19} an-anavakkas-na of rebels utterly destroyed; 27th day of month Anamaka pirk, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas; vasi Tassunos appo Hu\textsuperscript{20}nina then, thus the battle they fought; then people which of me aiki inni yuttas, Tahiyahus Kämpattas yesi Mata-pa-ikki, avi move(?) not made, province Campada named in Media, there patis, \textsuperscript{21}kus Hu sinnigat Mata-pa-ikki. remained, until I should go to Media.

Tifapa, in l. 13, is probably used as an explanatory complement to the verb tavon. Irsarra, "the leader," has the mark of distinction, because placed alone: when the word is combined with the name of a nation, as in l. 17, the distinctive mark is omitted, as though we should write "Leader" with a capital letter, and the same word in "army-leader" without the distinction. I have no idea of the meaning of arir, in l. 17, though it is just possible that it may be connected with arta "to stay;" the word does not occur again, and the Persian is lost. The date is clearly the 27th, as in the Babylonian version. In the Persian it is indistinct.

II. 7. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Tatar\textsuperscript{22}yesi, Arminiar and Darius king says:—Dadarshish named, Armenian
kir, Hu Lubaruri, ynfri Hu Arminiya-fa-ikki ir yuttu; yechitu one, my subject, him I to the Armenians him sent; thus "ye-tiriya: vita, Tassunos appo Patifa, Hu-nina inni tirivan pi, to him I said: go, people who rebels, of me not called who, yupi-pa-afpis vanka; vasni Tatargis *thak; thap Arminiya-fa-ikki them slay? then Dadarshish marched; when to Armenia ir-porikka, Patifa fruirsrarra-faba, Tatargis ir-va *šinnifa, he went, rebels assembling, Dadarshish to him they went, saprakimmas yuttininuhuba; vasni Tatargis saprakimmas ap-va-tas; battle making; then Dadarshish battle them to made; Yuvanis — Sutsa *yesi, Arminiya-fa-ikki, avi Auramasta pikti at a town Zuza named, in Armenia, there Ormazd helper Hu-tas, šanvin Auramasta-na Tassunos *appo Hu-nina Tassunos to me was, by favour of Ormazd people which of me people appo Pati-fa-na irsikki afpis; VIII annan among an-thurvar-na which of rebels utterly destroyed; 8th day of month Thuravahara pirka, *yechitu saprakimmas yuttas, then, thus the battle they fought.

The syllable va in ir-va, l. 24, and ap-va, l. 28, looks very much like a postposition; in Tatargis ir-va and similar phrases, the syllable ir seems to be inserted in a similar way to yufri, as a vehicle for carrying the particle which marks the grammatical case; as in Ntitpoal yufri-na, I. 75. The clause in l. 25, “then Dadarshish fought a battle with them,” is an addition to the Persian text.

II. 8. hiak sarak II-imnas-va, Pati-fa fruirsrarrapba, Tatargis and time at the second, rebels assembling, Dadarshish ir-va šinnifa, saprakimmas yuttininuhuba; vasni — Afvarris — Tikra to him went, battle making; then at a fort Tigris yesi, — Arminiya-fa-ikki, avi saprakimmas yuttas: Auramasta named, in Armenia, there the battle they fought: Ormazd pikti Hu-tas, šanvin Auramasta-na, Tassunos appo Hu-nina helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd, people which of me Tassunos appo Pati-fa-na irsikki afpis; XVIII annan among people which of rebels utterly destroyed; 18th day month an-thurvar-na *pirka, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas.

Observe the change of fa to ap in fruirsrarrapba, l. 28, shewing the
similarity of sounds. Observe also, here and elsewhere, that there is no mark of distinction before the name of a month, and that probably the case-ending na belongs to the compound expression, "of the month Thurasahara."

II. 9. hiak sarak III-immas-va Pati-fa fruir sarra-faba, Taštaršis and time at the third rebels assembling, Dadarshih ir-va šinnifa, saprakimmas yuttiniunhuba; Afvarris Huiyama to him went, battle making; at a fort Uhyama yesi, Arminiya-fa-ikki, avi saprakimmas yuttas; Auramasta named, in Armenia, there the battle they fought; Ormazd pikti Hu-tas, sauvia Auramasta-na Tassu-nos appo Hu-nilna helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd people which mine Tassunos appo Pati-fa-na iraiikki afsis; IX annan anmonš people which of rebels utterly destroyed; 9th day the month an-thahikerrichis-na, špirka, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas; hiak of Thasgarashih, thus, thus the battle they fought; and vasni Tataršis aški inni yuttas, Hun satis, škus Hu then Dadarshih a move(?) not made, me waited, until I Mata-pa-ikki sinnigat.

The close of this paragraph will not bear out the restoration of Armenia proposed by Oppert in the Persian text, l. 48. Aški is explained on pure conjecture; see I. 39 and II. 20. The usual wedge is omitted before Mata in l. 37.

II. 10. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Vaumissša yesi, Parsar kir, and Darius king says:— Vomises named, Persian one, Hu Lubaruri, yufri Hu tifapa Arminiya-fa-ikki taven, yešchitu my subject, him I envoy to the Armenians sent, thus ye-tiri: vita, Tassunos appo Pati-fa, Hu-nilna inni tirivan pi, to him said: go, people the rebels, mine not called who, yupi-pa afsis vanka; vasni Vaumissa thak; thap Arminiya-fa-ikki them destroy; ? then Vomises went; when to the Armenians ir-porikka, Patifa fruir sarra-faba, Vaumissa ir-va šinnifa, he went, rebels assembling, Vomises to him went, saprakimmas yuttiniunhuba; vasni Atchitu yesi, Assuran, battle making; then at Achidu named, in Assyria,
avi sapakimmas yuttas; Auramasta pikti Hu-tas, sauvin there the battle they fought; Ormazd helper to me was, by favour Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Hu-nina Tassunos appo Pati-fa-na of Ormazd people who mine people who of rebels irsikki afpis; XV annan anmon an-anamakkas-na, pirka, utterly destroyed; 15th day of the month Anamaks, then, ye chitu saprakimmas yuttas, thus the battle they fought.

The name Atchitu is lost in the Persian text, and in the Babylonian version also.

II. 11. hiak sarak II-immas-va, Pati-fa fruirsarra-faba, Vaumissat and time at the second rebels assembling, Vomises ir-va sinnifa, saprakimmas yuttiniunyuba; vasni Batin to him they went, battle making; then in a province Antiyarus yesi, avi saprakimas yuttas; Auramasta pikti Otiara named, there the battle they fought; Ormazd helper Hu-tas, sauvin Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Hu-nina Tassunos to me was, by favour of Ormazd people who of me people appo Pati-fa irsikki afpis; anmon an-thurvar puinkita va, who rebels utterly defeated; the month Thuravahara at end, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas; vasni Vaumissa Arminiya-fa-ikki thus the battle they fought; then Vomises in Armenia satias, kus Hu Mata-pa-ikki sinnigat. stayed, until I to Media should go.

In l. 45, we have yuttiniunyuba, instead of the usual yuttiniunyuba. Puinkita-va does not occur elsewhere, but the Babylonian version proves the meaning, in accordance with Benfey's sagacious conjecture: the omission of the usual annan and pirka in l. 47, with the corresponding omission in the Persian, form the authority for dividing the words expressing the dates. The explanatory words "a district of Armenia," found necessary in the Persian text, after mention of the name of Otiara, are omitted in the Scythic; if this be not simply an accident, it may be inferred that the district was well known to the tribes by whom the language was spoken.

II. 12. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasni Hu Bapila-mar and Darius king says:— then I from Babylon
lachogatta, Mata-pa-ikki poriya; thap Maota-pa-ikki in-porugat,
retired, to Media I went; when at Media I arrived,

Afa Kuntarrus yesi, Mata-pa-ikki, avi Fruvartis yufri siunnik
at a town Gundrusia named, in Media, there Phraortes he came

akka nanri, Hu Ko-vas Mata-pa-na yutta-vara, saprakimmas
who said, I king of Media am, battle

yuttivan-ra; vasni saprakimmas yuttayut; Auramasta pikti Hu-tas,
making; then the battle we fought; Ormazd helper to me was,

sanvin Auramasta-na avi Tassunos appo Fruvartis-na Hu afpi
by favour of Ormazd there people who of Phraortes I destroyed

insikki; XXV aunan among an-atukannas-na pirk, yechitu
utterly; 25th day of the month Adukanna then, thus

sprakimmas yuttihut.

the battle we fought.

Observe the varied orthography of yuttayut in l. 51-2, and yuttihut
at the close of the paragraph: see also the distinctive singular parti-
ciple yuttivan-ra in l. 51. At the beginning of l. 53, in afpi ireikki,
it appears that the usual terminating the syllable ya was unnecessary
before a similar vowel. The name of the month in the same line is
lost in the Persian, and does not occur elsewhere.

II: 13. vasni "Fruvartis yufri Talni-fa arikki-fa itaka
then Phraortes he horsemen faithful with

putraskas, Rakkan thak; vasni Hu Tassunos-vas smi taven;
marching, to Rhages went; then I the people mine sent;

avi-mar marrika, Hu-ikki nogaiik; Hu yegim-vas, hiak tit-vas,
there-from he was seized, to me he was brought; I his nose, and tongue,

hiak peri vachchiya, reta'kituva; Chifa Hu-ninna rabbaka
and ears cut off, I smote him(?); court my in chained

marrik; Tassunos marpafa-ta ir chiyas; hiak vasni Akvatana
he was held; people all him saw; and then at Ecbatana

at'rar-va ir patu, hiak kutta Yoş appo atarrivan nitavi yupo-su
on cross him I put, and also men who followers his chiefs

pi, yupi-pa Akvatana Afvarri-s-va vartes appini surakve-poka
who, them at Ecbatana in citadel ? put again enclosed(?)

appin pers.
them hanged (?).

Observe again the omission of explanatory words in the Scythic
version, as in Par. XI; we have here a Median city, aj ly
known to the people who spoke this language, and which subsequently became the capital of the Parthian empire. In l. 56 I render *tit* "tongue" in preference to "lips," because it looks more like a singular than a plural, and the addition of *vas* is shewn by the following word *peri* to be unnecessary or unusual in the plural: this is however nothing more than a guess. *Reçakituvu* is likely to be a verb of the first person singular, but the signification is unknown; it may be a noun with the locative post-position. The last line is quite unintelligible to me: it contains a character not found elsewhere, and another which I read *kwe*, found also in the independent Inscription III., where it constitutes a part of the same uncertain word *kwe-poka*, probably a participle; the meaning may be "confined."

II. 14. hiak Tariyavans Ko nanri:—Ruven kir Chissaintakma and Darius king said:— man one Chitratakma yesi, Assagartiya-ra, yufri Hu-ikki-mar pafarsaka, Tassunos-pa named, a Sagartian, he from me revolting, to the people yechitu ap-tiris nanri: Ko-vas Hu yutta, Nivanş Vakštarra-na thus them addressed said: king I am, family of Cyaxares niman vara; vas Hu Tassunos Parsan hiak Mata-pa tifapa descended am; then I people Persian and Median envoy(?) taven; Takmasbata yesi, Matn, Hu Lubarnri, yufri Irarra sent; Tachmaspates named, a Mede, my subject, him leader appin ir yutta, yechitu ap-tiriya: vitas, Tassunos appo appointed him I made, thus them I addressed: go, people which Pati-fa, Hu-nina innl tirivan pi, yupi-pa afpis vanka; vas rebels, mine not called who, them slay: ? then Takmasbata Tassunos itaka thak; saprakimmas Chissaintakma Tachmaspates people with marched; the battle Chitratakma ye-tas; Auramasta pikti Hu-tiis, savin Auramasta-na, with him fought; Ormazd helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd, Tassunos appo Hu-nina Tassunos appo Pati-fa-pa irsikki afpis, kutta people who mine people who to rebels wholly destroyed, and Chissaintakma ir marris, Hu-ikki ir nogas; Hu yeşim-vas, Chitratakma him they took, to me him they brought; I his nose, hink peri vachchi, roçakituvu; Chišfa Hu-nina-va rabbaka, and ears cut off, I amote him(?), palace mine in chained, marrik; Tassunos marripafa-ta ir chiyna; vas Hu Arpars yoni, he was held; people all him saw; then in Arbaa named, Hu atru-r-va ir patu.

I on cross him I put.
BEHISTUN INSCRIPTION.

Observe aiya l. 60: cf. with aiya, in l. 10-1. Pati-fa-pa, in l. 64, "to the rebels," in other instances Pati-fa-na. The ta in aiya, l. 68, is certainly the indefinite "soever," and the same in l. 56. I know not whether aiya should be divided as aiya ira ira patu, or aiya ira ira patu; in the former case ira will be like the ira in ira-pa, so often repeated; see II. 24; my own opinion is rather in favour of the latter. That the meaning is "fixed on the cross," is shewn by the Babylonian version. The horizontal wedge before Assagartiya, in l. 59, is irregular.

II. 15. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—ye Hu Mata-pa-ikki
and Darius king says:—this I in Media
yutta.

II. 16. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Parthuvas-pa hiak
and Darius king says:—Parthians and
Virkaniya-fa Hu-ikki-mar pafati-faba, Fru-vartis-na tiriyas;
Hyremians from me revolting, of Fruvartis called themselves;
Vistaiba Hu Attata Parthuvas senri, ir yufri Tassunos
Hystaspes my father in Parthis was, him people
ir-vach tavassa pafati-fa; hiak vasni Vistaiba Tassunos appo tavini
him forming revolted; and then Hystaspes people who his
itaka thak; Afsh Visbaušatis nyesi, Parthuvas, avii
with maredh; at a town Hypaozatis named, in Parthis, there
saprakimmas Pati-fa ap-va-tas; Auramasta pikti Hu-tas;
the battle rebels against them fought; Ormazd helper to me was,
ganvin Auramasta-na Vištaiba Tassunos appo Pati-fa afsis
by favour of Ormazi Hystaspes people who rebels destroyed
insikki; XXII annan amons an-viyakamna-na pirkas, yechitu
utterly; 23rd day of the month Viyakhma then, thus
saprakimmas yutta.
the battle they fought.

This paragraph is lost in the Persian, and I am unable to give
a better translation than Colonel Rawlinson has proposed: in L 69,
tiriyas is a new form, denoting probably a reflected sense (See p. 96).
The passage in L 69-76 is different from any other
in the inscriptions, and the word new one; compared
with the same
together wit
ending
Persian word *avarada*, it will appear almost certain that the meaning given is correct. *Yufri* looks like the subject, and *Tassunos* like the object; but the plural verb *pafatifa* must show that *Tassunos* is the nominative case, and *ir* with *yufri* must make an accusative. The second *ir* probably makes *pafatifa* verbal, in spite of the intervening word. *Tavi-ni*, in l. 70, must be identical with *ni-tavi*; but the transposition is curious.

III. 1. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasnī Hu Tassunos Parsan and Darius king says:—then I people Persian

Rakkan-mar Vistaśba-ikki nogaya; thap Tassunos yupi-pa from Rhages to Hystaspes sent; when people these

Vistaśba-ikki ir-porifa, vasnī Vistaśba Tassunos yupi-pa itaka to Hystaspes came, then Hystaspes people these with

thak; Afṣ Patikrabbana yesi, Parthuvas, avi marched; at a town Patigrabana called, in Parthia, there

saprakimmas yuttās; Auramasta pikti Hu-tās, sauvin the battle they fought; Ormazd helper to me was, by favour

Auramasta-na Vistaśba Tassunos appo Pati-fa afsip irsikki; of Ormazd Hystaspes people who rebels destroyed utterly;

I annan anmonś an-garśmapatās pirka, yechitu saprakimmas 1st day of month Garapada then, thus the battle

yuttās. they fought.

The only peculiarity observable in this paragraph is the omission of the genitive particle after the name of the month in l. 77.

III. 2. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasnī Tahiyahu's Hu-nīna and Darius king says:—then the province mine ayuttafa; ye Hu Parthuvas yutta. became; this I in Parthia did.

Compare this paragraph with the 15th, line 67; I should have expected a postposition after *Parthuvas*, or at least the mark denoting locality.

III. 3. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Tahiyahu's Markus and Darius king says:—province Margiana
yesi Hu-ikki-mar pafati-faba, Ruven kir Frata yesi, Markus-irra,
named from me revolting, man one Phrnates named, a Margian,
yufri "Ko appinl ir yuttas; hink vasni Hu Tataris yesi, Parsar
him king appointed him made; and then I Dadares named, Persian
kir, Hu Lubaruri, Saksabavana-vas Ba'kshis yuttas, yutro
one, my subject, [who] the satrap in Bactria was, envoy
yufrikki nogaya; nanga: vitkini, Tassunos appo Pati-fa Hu-nina inni
to him I sent; I said: go, people who rebels, of me not
tirvan pi, "yupi-pa afpis ni vanka; vasni Tataris Tassunos itaka
called who, them slay? then Dadares people with
thak; saprakimmas Markus-pa ap-va-tas, Auramasta pikti
marched; the battle Margians to them fought, Ormazd helper
"Hu-tas, sauvin Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Hu-nina Tassunos
to me was, by favour of Ormazd people who mine people
appo Patifa-na afpis irsikki; XXIII annan "anmona
who of rebels destroyed utterly; 23rd day of the month
an-amiyatiyas-na pirkas, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas.
Ariyatiya then, thus the battle they fought.

Pafati-faba, l. 79, is, I think, a plural form, notwithstanding its
grammatical connection with a single province: but the word Tahi-
yesus is almost invariably looked upon as a plural. In the same
line Markus-irra appears to be singular (conf. III. 56), but the
passage looks ambiguous here, as in the Persian text. We have
"king" instead of "leader" in l. 80, and the form is Ko instead of
Ko-ves. I cannot explain nanga nor vitkini: the former word is clearly
connected with nanri, and the latter with vita and vitas; nor does
there appear any meaning in the syllable ni after afpis in l. 82: it
cannot be supposed that there is any connection with nivonki of
II. 10-1.

III. 4. hiak Tariyavaus Ko na'nri:— vasni Tahiyahus Hu-nina
and Darius king says:— then Province mine
ayuttasa; ye Hu Ba'kshis yutta.
became; this I in Bactria did.

With the exception of the name of the province, this paragraph is
identical with the second: but we have the wedge of locality which
was wanted there.
COLUMN III.

The third Scythic column, to which we are now arrived, is very much damaged, particularly on the left side, down the whole extent of which there is a wide band with hardly a letter visible. The mutilation was so great in the upper half, that Colonel Rawlinson did not take a connected impression, but contented himself with detached bits, which are here brought together. Luckily this part comprises the historical portion corresponding with the third Persian Column, and it may be generally restored with confidence. This is not the case with the lower half, corresponding with the fourth of the Persian Columns; where, as observed before, we have so many varieties of construction: our restorations in that part will be more sparing, and given with much less confidence.

III. 5. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Ruen kir Vistatta yesi,
and Darius king says:— man one Veisdates named,
→ Afg Tarrahua yesi, Ihtuyas yesi, Parsan-ikki, avi artak;
in a town Tarva named, Iotia named, in Persia, there he dwelled;
yufri sarak II-immas-va Parsan-ikki ivaka, Tassunos-pa.
he time at the second in Persia arising, to the people
ap-tiris nanri: Hu Bartiyes tar kuras-na; cesni Thessanos
them addressing said: I [am] Bardes son of Cyrus; then people
Parsan appo Hu revanni → Anṣutis ......poka, yupi-pa Hu-ikki-mar
Persian who I at home(?) stayed(?) they from me
pafatifa, yufrikki poris; Parsan-ikki Ko-vas yufri yuttas.
revolting, to him deserted; in Persia king he became.

The damaged bit in l. 3 is of uncertain signification in the Persian text; sa may be a part of satis “stayed;” but this is very doubtful; and the wedge of locality placed before the uncertain character preceding sa adds to the unsatisfactory nature of the explanation here set down.

III. 6. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:— Hu
and Darius king says:—
reva yu Ἰν-ικκι-μαρ inni pafatim, yupi-pa hiak Taasu'nos Parsan
with ? from me not revolting, them and the people Persian
hiak Mata-pa appo Hu-tas, yupi-pa tifapa tavon; Artavartiya yesi,
and Median who with me, them envoya I sent; Artabordes named,
Parsar kir, Hu Lubaruri, *yufri Irsarra appini ir yutta; hiak Persian one, my subject, him leader appointed him I made; and kutta Tassunos Parsan tahi ir-porik Mata-pa-ikki Hu-kik; hiak *vasni also army Persian another went to Media after me; and then Artavartiya Tassunos itaka Parsan-ikki thak; thap Parsan-ikki Artabardes people with to Persia marched; when Persia ir-porik, Afş Rakkan *yesi Parsan-ikki, ............... avi he reached, at a town Racha named, in Persia, there Vistaţta, yufri akka nanri, Hu Bartiya, tassunos itaka, Artavartiya Veisdates, he who said, I [am] Bardes, people with, Artabardes ir-va sinnik, saprakimmas yuttivan-ra; hiak vasni saprakimmas to him went, the battle about to fight; and then the battle yuttas; Auramasta *pikti Hu-tüs, souvin Auramasta-na they fought; Ormazd helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd Tassunos appo Hu-nîna Tassunos appo Vistaţta-na afpis ir*šikki; people who mine people who of Veisdates destroyed wholly; XII annan anmons an-thurvar-na pirka, yechitu saprakimmas 12th day of the month Thuravahara then, thus the battle yuttas.

At the beginning of this paragraph mention was probably made of some other Persian troops, which did not partake in the general revolt; but the passage obliterated is additional, and did not exist either in the Persian text or Babylonian version. The Persian town of Râcha, in l. 8, is not graphically distinguished from that of the Median Rhages in II. 54, an evidence that the language confounded the sonant and aspirate sounds in pronunciation; as there was an obvious mode of distinguishing the two in this case by substituting *š* for *š*, had there been any difference in the sound. In the Persian text the difference is well marked. I cannot fill up the space in l. 9, and the restoration at the commencement of l. 10 is uncertain. There is fair authority for all the other restorations.

III. 7. hiak vasni Vistaţta yufri Talni-fa ariki-fa itaka and then Veisdates he horsemen faithful with Pipiyauvata putraska, ...........ir-va poris; avi-mar sarak Tassunos to Pissinadha marching, to him went; thence again people yufri Artavartiya ir-va sinnik, saprakimmas yuttivanra; Afş him Artabardes to him went, the battle about to fight; in town
Parraka yesi, avi saprakimmas yutta's; Auramasta pikti
Parga named, there the battle they fought; Ormazd helper
Hu-täi, sauvin Auramasta-na Tassunos appo Hu-nina hiak Tassunos
to me was, by favour of Ormazd people who mine and people
appo Vis'tatta-na ireikki appis; VI annan amnon
who of Veisdates entirely destroyed; 6th day of the month
an-garmapatàs-na pïka, yechitu saprakimmas yutta's, hiak kut'as
Garmapada, then, thus the battle they fought, and also
Vista'tta yufri marries, hiak Yoš appo atarrivan nitavi yupo-fa pi
Veisdates him they took, and men the followers his chiefs who
marries, captured.

The restorations in lines 13 and 14 are both somewhat uncertain,
although there cannot be much doubt about the meaning of the para-
graph; in the name of Parga in l. 14, the first letter may be ṣ or
ṣ, the second is quite lost. The word hiak near the end of l. 15
is quite irregular, and must be an error of the engraver.

III. 8. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—vasni Vista'tta yufri hiak
and Darius king says:—then Veisdates him and
Yoš appo atarrivan nitavi yupo-fa pi i'taka tachis......................
men the followers his chiefs who with ?

There is room at the beginning of l. 19 to restore the word itaka,
and although apparently ungrammatical, it is justified by the example
in l. 44-5. The name of the town Uvadaidiya, where the punishment,
whatever it was, was inflicted, is omitted: there could hardly have
been room for the word in the space left on the rock; though I have
been tempted to look for it in the tachis which is perfectly clear on the
impression. The indistinct ṣ might have been ṣ, and there
is room for ṣ, which would make the name Uvatachis; but as we
should have to alter the ṣ of the Persian to ṣ, and as the town
would not be more easily identified under the name of Uvadachis than
Uvadaidiya, it is not very likely that my conjecture will be accepted.

hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—ye Hu Parsan-ikki yu'ha
and Darius king says:—this I in Persia did.

This paragraph is not in the Persian text, but is found in the
BEHISTUN INSCRIPTION.

The transactions were perhaps too well known among the Persians to require the usual formula to be appended in that language.

9. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Vistatta yufri akka nanri, and Darius king says:—Veisdates he who said, artiya, yufiri Tassunos Arrauvatis tifapa taven; Yog kir ardes, he people Arachosia had sent out; man one appini ir yuttas, Vivana yesi Parsarpra, Hu Lubaruri, appointed him was, Vibanus named a Persian, my subject, ana-vas Arrauvatis yuttas, yufrikki; yechitu ap-tiris: strap of Arachosia was, against him; thus he them addressed: vana afpis, kutta Tassunos yupi-pa akka-pa Tariyavaus banus slay, and people those who of Darius tirivan pi vara: vasni Tassunos yupi-pa — Arrauvatis called who? then people those to Arachosia tki poris, akka Vistatta tifapa taven; Afvarris is went, which Veisdates had sent out; at a fort sekanis yesi Arrauvatis-ikki, avi saprakimmas yuttas; canis named in Arachosia, there the battle they fought; ta pikti Hu-täs, sauvin Auramas ta-na Tassunos appo helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd people who Tassunos appo Patifa-na afpis irsikki; XIII annan people who of rebels defeated utterly; 13th day an-anamakkas-na pirkka, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas. month Anamaka then, thus the battle they fought.

There is a good deal of uncertainty about the grammatical construction in this paragraph, although the meaning is plain enough; the phrase in l. 21, is uncommon; the impression is very faint, and the word after all be Ruven. The pronoun ir before yuttas, in the use, is unintelligible to me, and I can only account for it being an inadvertence on the part of the writer, who may have been misled by the frequent appearance of ir before the word yuttas, which sound to yuttas. I cannot account for the addition of vara in the usual formula in l. 23; the only difference between this and similar cases is, that the speaker is here the third person, speaks elsewhere in the first person. Arrauvatis in l. 26
III. 10. *hiak sarab II-immas-va*, Pati-fa fruirarra-faba, and time at the second, rebels assembling, saprakimmas Vivana ita*ka, Batin Kantuvata yesi, avi battle Vibanus with, in district Gandytia named, there yuttas; Auramasta pikti Hu-tas, sauvin Auramasta-na Tassunos they fought; Ormazd helper to me was, by favour of Ormazd people appo Hu-nina Tassunos oppo Patifa-na appis irsikki; VII annan who mine people who of rebels destroyed utterly; 7th day anmon an-viyakannas-na, pirka, yechitu saprakimmas yuttas, of the month of Viyakhna, then, thus the battle they fought.

The formula which usually follows the assembling of the rebels is omitted in this paragraph, though inserted in the Persian text. The name of the district called Gadutava in the Persian text, appears on the rock under a very different form; I suspect the engraver left out a wedge in the first letter, making instead of , and the word should have been "Kantuvata;" this would have been a fair representation of the name, and as such I have restored it.

III. 11. *hiak vaeni Ruven akka Tassunos-na irsarra Vistasia* and then man who people's leader Veidates ir yuttasti, yufiri Talni-fa arikki-fa itaka psirasko thak; him had made, he horsemen faithful with marching went; Afvarris Irsata yesi, Arrauvatis, Irval *Vivana-na, to a fort Arsada named, of Arachosia, the dwelling-place(?) of Vibanus, avi lufaba; vaeni Vivana Tassunos itaka eari ir-porik, hiak there he retired; then Vibanus people with following went, and avi Ruven yufri akka Tas*sunos-na irsarra oppini yuttasti, hiak there man he who people's leader appointed had been, and Xos akka atarrivan nitavi yupo-fa pi, maurissa, appin afpis. men who followers his chiefs who, he took, and them he slew.

At the beginning, the word yufri or kir perhaps should have been restored after Ruven; there is ample space for it, as the paragraphs generally follow close, when the usual commencing formula is omitted. The word Irval, l. 32, is not found elsewhere, and the phrase may mean "the dwelling place of Vibanus;" or "the property of Vibanus;" it is omitted in the Persian, and the Babylonian is lost. As Vibanus was Satrap of Arachosia, this is a probable meaning; and there are Ugrian analogies which may support the meaning suggested (see
Vocabulary). The word which I have read vasri in line 32, is made sawri in the lithograph; the first character is very faint. I should decide at once for vasri, but I fear there is no precedent for the word.

III. 12. hiak Tariyavous Ko nanri:—vasni Tahiyahus Hu-nina and Darius king says:—then the province mine ayuttafa; ye Hu Arrauvatis yutta. became: this I in Arachosia did.

This paragraph requires no remark.

III. 13. hiak Tariyavous Ko nanri:—kus Hu Parsan-ikki hiak and Darius king says:—while I in Perais Mata-pa-ikki sennigat, sarak II-immas-va Bapilu-fa pafatiya; in Media was, time at the second Babylonians revolted; Ruen kir Arakka yesi, Arminiya-rkir, Aftita Sakri, yufri man one Aracus named, an Armenian, Haddita's son, he Afš Tubanna yesi Bapilu ivake, avimar yufri yechitu at a town Dubana named in Babylonia arising, from there he thus tiraska Tassunos-pa ap-tiris, nauiri: Hu Nabuškutarrusar, tar lying to the people them he spoke, he said: I [am] Nabuchodrosser, son nabonite; hiak vaeni Tassunos Bapilu-fa Hu-ikki-mar pafati-faba of Nabonides; and then people Babylonian from me revolting, Arakka yufrikški poris; hiak Bapilu yufri marris, Ko-vas to him Aracus deserted; and Babylon he captured, king Bapilu yufri yuttas. of Babylon he became.

The uncertainty of the sound of the Persian ḥrenders the determination of the power of ḥ uncertain: I am inclined to make it av or am; in the following line the Scythic nasal is distinct, in the name of the town which contains the only other example of the Persian ḥ.

III. 14. hiak vasni Hu Tassunos Bapišlu-pa-fa tavem; and then I people to Babylonia sent; Vintoporna yesi, Mata, Hu Lubaruri, yufri Hu Irsarra appini Intaphres named, a Median, my subject, him I leader appointed ir yutta, yečchitu ap-tiriya: vites, Tassunos Bapilu-fa akka-pa him made, thus to them said: go, people Babylonian who
Hu-niña inni tirivan pi, yu-pa afsis vanka; hiak vasni
of me not called who, them slay; ? and then
Všntaparna Tassunos itaka Bapilu poris; Astramasta pikti
Intaphres people with to Babylon went; Ormazd helper
Hu-täs, sanvin Auramasta-na Vinštaparna Bapilu morris,
to me was, by favour of Ormazd Intaphres Babylon captured,
Hu-ikki Tassunos appin farpis; XXII annan among
to me the people them made prisoners; 22nd day of the month
an-markašanas-na, pirkä, yešchitu Arakka yufri akka namri, Hu
of Markazana, then, thus Aracus he who said, I
Nabukutarusar vara, marrik, hiak Yoš appo atarrivan nitavi
Nabuchodonosor am, was seized, and men who followers his
yu-pa fa pi itaka, marrika, rabbaka, ............... Hu sira; Arakka
chiefs who with, was taken, chained, on crosses(?) I placed(?); Aracus
yufri hiak Yoš akka-pa atarrišvan nitavi yupo-pa pi itaka,
he and men who followers his chiefs who with,
Bapilu Hu-ikki-mar pafalufa.
in Babylon by me were slain.

The restorations in this paragraph may be considered hazardous,
but the object of the whole paragraph cannot be doubtful. The month
Markazana does not occur elsewhere, and it has a curious resemblance
to the Jewish Marchesvan, which corresponds with our October or
November; a probable epoch. Hu-ikki in l. 43, may have been irsikki,
but the general meaning would not thereby be affected. The Baby-
lonian version decides the rendering of the word which I have made
farpis in the plate, though it may have been parpis, a word equally
unknown to me. Sira, in l. 45, must certainly be a verb; I once
supposed that it might be a postposition, meaning coram, and that the
phrase may have been hiak nogaiq Hu-sira, “and was brought before
me;” but the other construction is more in accordance with the
Van Inscription, No. xvi, where sira is niyashtáyam, and I think siras
is niyashtáya.

IV. 1. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanšri:—ye Hu > Bapilu yutta.
and Darius king says:—this I in Babylon did.

We have in this paragraph, which is repeated like a formula,
another example of the localizing value of the horizontal wedge.

IV. 2. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—ye appo Hu yutta,
and Darius king says:—this [is] what I did,
Palkišva šauvin Auramasta-na Hu yutta; yechitu Hu yutta; always by favour of Ormazd I have done; thus I did;

XIX Pat yutta, šauvin Auramasta-na Hu appin afpiya, in 19 battles I fought, by favour of Ormazd I them conquered, hiak IX Ko-fa Hu mauriya; kir Gaumatta yesi, Makus, tiraska and 9 kings I captured; one Gomates named, a Magian, lying nanri, Hu Bartišya tar kuras-na, yufri Parsan pafatās; hiak said, I [am] Bardes son of Cyrus, he Persia made rebel; and Aśina yesi, Afar ra, yufri Afarti-fa appin pafatās sa nanri, Atrines named, a Susian, he the Susians them making rebel said, Ko-vas Afarti-fa-na Hu yutavara; hiak Nititpaal yesi, Bapilu-rkir, king of Susiana I am; and Naditabiru named, a Babylonian, tiraska nanri, Hu Nabukutarrusa tar napunita, yufri Bapilu-fa lying said, I [am] Nabuchodrossor son of Nabonidus, he Babylonia pafatis; hiak Martiya yesi, Parsar-kir, tiraska nanri, Hu made rebel; and Martius named, a Persian, lying said, I [am] Immannis, Ko Afarti-fa-na, yufri Afarti-fa pafatās; hiak Fruvartis Imanes, king of Susiana, he Susians made rebel; and Phrortes yesi, Mata, tišraska nanri, Hu Sattarritta Nimans Vakstarra-na named, a Median, lying said, I Xathrites of the race of Cyaxares vara, yufri Mata-pa apin pafatās; hiak Chišsaintakma yesi, am, he Medians them made rebel; and Chitratakhma named, Assagartiya-ra, tiraska nanri, Ko-vas Hu yutta, Nimans Vakstarra-na a Sagartian, lying said, king I am, of the race of Cyaxares vara, yufri Assagartiya-fa pafatās; hiak Frata yesi, Markus-irra, am, he Sagartians made rebel; and Phraates named, a Margian, tiraska nanri, Ko-vas Markus-pa-na Hu yutta, yufri Markus-pa lying said, king of the Margians I am, he the Margians pafatās; hiak Vistatta yesi, Parsar-ra, tiraska nanri, Hu made rebel; and Veisdates named, a Persian, lying said, I [am] Bartišya, tar kuras-na, yufri Parsan appin pafatās; hiak Arakka Bardes, son of Cyrus, he Persia them made rebel; and Aracus yesi, Arminiya-ra, tiraska nanri, Hu Nabukutarrusa tar named, an Armenian, lying said, I Nabuchodrossor son nanunita-na vara, yufri Bapilu-fa apin pafatās.

The restorations are all probable, except perhaps in l. 48; in that clause the Persian, according to Colonel Rawlinson's correction, as

vol. xv.
given in his Notes, p. v, reads, "This was all done by the grace of Ormazd; and as the kings rebelled, I fought nineteen battles, and by the grace of Ormazd I won them, and took nine kings captive." I would have wished to restore in the damaged space some such phrase as *thap Koṣa pafatifa, yechitu Hu*, but there was not room for it, so that I have left the words which I had at first inserted as a mere guess. The word *Palkiva* expresses here and elsewhere the phrase *hamahyáj thrada*, of the Persian, but throws no light on the singular word *thrada*; it neither confirms nor refutes the conjecture of Oppert, who connects it with سال, "a year." I have always been inclined, fancifully I admit, to connect the meaning with our English "thread," "the tale," "narrative." The word *Pat*, "battle," both here and in l. 60, may be *Pafar*; the preceding numeral looks like ١٠٠ but I should suppose it must be ١٠٠. One of the kings only, Atrines, is not mentioned as an impostor, but as he has elsewhere the usual *tiraska* attached to him, this is probably an inadvertence. The irregularity of the Scythic language, or its love of variety, is shewn in this paragraph; in the Persian text, all the clauses are constructed precisely upon the same model, as though by an official formula; but in the Scythic no two are exactly alike; in one case, that of Atrines, the expression is inverted, and at the close of all the others the clause "he made them rebel" is written variously *appin pafatàs, appin pafatàs, pafatàs* only, and once *pafatis*. This variety can be charged only to the unfixedness of the language. Remark the irregularity of the orthography of Nabonidus in l. 52, where the engraver has written the word phonetically, instead of using the ordinary ideograph ♦♦♦ for Nebo.

IV. 3. hiak Ta'riyavaus Ko nanri:—Appin ye IX Ko-fa and Darius king says:— These [are] 9 kings appo Hu pat ye ativa mauriya. whom I battles these in captured.

The restoration of *appin* is doubtful, the space is greater than wanted for the word, and the perpendicular wedge, quite visible, is unusual before *appin*.

IV. 4. hiak "Tariyavaus Ko nanri:— Tahiyaus ye appo and Darius king says:— provinces these which pafatifa pi; appi titkimas appin pa'fatàs, appo appi rebelled which god of lies them made rebel, that they
I feel certain that appi, in l. 61, means "a false god," even without the addition of titkimas: it is the word used for the gods worshipped by the Persians, read annappi without the determinative \( \rightarrow \), which means "celestial," occurring as it does before, or a constituent part of the words meaning "heaven," "day," "month," as well as "god;" perhaps the Zyrarian yen "god" may retain this sound. The Persian corresponding phrase may then be restored in this way, "Daraugadiva hamitriyá akunaush," see Rawlinson, Notes, p. vi. The next clause I cannot restore. Ormazd appears in the following clause, both here and in the Babylonian version, as equivalent to the Persian term of which Di...... alone is left; and this is in some degree confirmatory of the above rendering. If Ormazd is in the nominative case, yuttás is put irregularly for yuttás, as at Persepolis, and oppin being accusative supports this rendering. The last clause is pretty clear, but the Persian is damaged, and the half word remaining after avatha can hardly have been correctly given; I have restored anirachitu in l. 63, from a passage in vi. 31, with a similar Persian equivalent.

IV. 5. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Ni, "Ko, Akka vasišin and Darius king says:—thou, king, who hereafter nikti, ....... tartuka tuin nisgas; yoš-irra titain-ra, yufri mayst be, in retribution ? protect; the man [who is] a liar, him tartuka viallu .................................. ti, Tahiyahus-mi tarva in retribution much punish. If thus thou continue, my province whole astu, shall be (?).

Nikti is restored from l. 83; the last letter is clear. A comparison of I. 18, III. 68, 75, 87, shews that tartuka must mean "returning," either good or evil. The end I do not see through; tarva occurs again in vi. 41 and iii. 16, but this gives me no light.

IV. 6. hiak Tariyavaus "Ko nanri:—ye appo Hu yutta; and Darius king says:—this [is] what I did; sowin Auramasta-na palkiva yutta; hiak Ni akka vasišin by favour of Ormazd always I have done; and thou who hereafter
SCYTHIC VERSION OF THE

— Ti'pi ye pahuranra, — Tipi ye-va riluik,
Tablet this mayest peruse, whatever thou seest on this tablet written,
yuvenpa uris, hini titkimmas reman'ti.
thus declare, do not falsehood judge.

The rendering of the last clause has been adopted from the unmistakeably prohibitive character of hini, and the probability that the last word is in the second person. The Persian varna which is represented by our uris, may be the Sanskrit वर्ण "to describe:" see संवर्ण, &c. The sense will be "what thou seest written do not think false." This is consistent with the Persian, where Colonel Rawlinson saw āja in a subsequent visit to the rock, which may perhaps allow us to suggest the restoration māya duruja maniyāya.

IV. 7. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri: — ankiri-ni Auramasta
and Darius king says: — witness to thee Ormaad
ra, thap appo ye peri inni titki'mmas Hu palkiva yutta.
be, that what this? not falsehood I always have made.

The letter preceding Auramasta is certainly ni, and corresponds with tayya seen by Colonel Rawlinson. Peri is the Persian kashiyam, but the meaning is uncertain.

IV. 8. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri: — sauvin Auramasta-na
and Darius king says: — by favour of Ormaad
tahiki-ta. Hu-nina irsikk'i yuttak senri appo tipi ye-va inni
other things by me greatly done there are which tablet on this not
riluik, yupainraskimmas hini Akka — Tipi ye vasi'sin
are written, for that reason let him not who tablet this hereafter
parana — pi-mar appo Hu-nina yuttak, yufri inni
shall peruse which by me is done, he not
urinra titkimas revan'tri.
related false may think.

All former translations of this passage have been given with much doubt, and are really very unsatisfactory. Opport rejects them all, and proposes none. The large lacuna in l. 71 prevents our drawing any conclusion from the Scythic version which can be accepted as quite positive; but the following is proposed as at least consistent:—

"Other great deeds have been done by me which are not written upon this tablet; but because those other deeds done by me are not related,
let him who shall hereafter peruse this tablet, not think for that reason that they are lies." Colonel Rawlinson's correction of nishim "non ea," for nishida (see his Notes), certainly countenances this reading, in the Persian text as well as Scythic version.

IV. 9. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Akka-pa Ko-fa irpifa and Darius king says: — those who kings before pi, kus senpafa, yupi-pa-na ye nifabak inni "yuttak, thap Hu who, while they were, of them this ? not was done, as I varrita savin Auramasta-na yutta. all by favour of Ormazd have done.

The unknown and damaged words in this paragraph prevent a full rendering, but the general sense must be something in this way: "The kings my predecessors, although they reigned a long time, did not such deeds as I, by the favour of Ormazd, have done." The word following "kings" is doubtfully read, and does not appear to occur elsewhere. I have restored palkiva in the lithograph, l. 73, but Colonel Rawlinson's Notes, p. vi, shew that the word thrada did not exist on the rock, and I write therefore varrita instead of palkiva.

IV. 10. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—am Ni uris "appo and Darius king says:—? thou declare what Hu yutta; yechitu yupainraskimas hini tartinti; hiak anka I have done; thus therefore do not conceal; and if lalne ye inni tartinti, Tassunos apin tirinti, Aura75masta record this not thou conceal, the people them thou tell, Ormazd Ni inkanIs-nI, hiak kitinti Nimans-nI, hiak kutta viallu thee befriend thee, and be to thee thy family, s and also very -iktaka takti-nI.

long be thy life.

I am not quite satisfied with either the sound or value of the character I have called am, in l. 73; it is found also in l. 23, 33, and appears to allude to something past; the character ṣṣṣṣ is supposed to be read tin, from its occurrence here, but it is not found elsewhere, and the considerations detailed after the syllabarium in p. 51 render it unlikely; lulne, the Persian hadugam, is probably "record," as conjectured by Colonel Rawlinson, and connected with rilu "to write." Tassunos apin looks like a dative for Tassunos-pa, but there is no other instance of its use. I cannot analyse the last bit; in l. 87 we find
viallu taka rasti-ni, having the same equivalent in Persian; perhaps vialluik may be one word, an adverb verbalized, meaning "be it long;" such a construction seems consistent with the usage of this class of languages; there may be an analogy between taka and takti, "life" and "live," or "continuance" and "continue."

IV. 11. hiak anka sarak julne ye ṭartin'tta, Tassunos inni and if again record this thou conceal, people not tirinta, Auramasta Nin afsis-ni, hiak kutta Nimang-ni hini tell, Ormazd thee destroy thee, and also family thy not kitinti. be to thee.

IV. 12. hiak Tariyavau'ts Ko nanri:—ye oppo Hu yutta, and Darius king says:—this which I have done, sauvin Auramasta-na Palkiva yutta; Auramasta annap by favour of Ormazd always I have done; Ormazd god Arriyanam pik'tti Hu-täs, hiak annap appo tahifa appo senri pi. of Arians helper to me was, and gods the others who are who.

I rather think the word Arriyanam to be a literal transcript of the Persian genitive case plural; it is not found in the version made for the Babylonians, who were, no doubt, too well acquainted with mythology to be ignorant of the position of this deity. The last letter of the paragraph is either or or or . The latter has been taken, as the most likely; all that is visible is , made neither like nor , and there is not room for a fair-sized wedge before it to make .

IV. 13. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—yuvenpainraskimas and Darius king says:—for this cause Auramas'tta annap Arriyanam pikti, hiak kutta annap appo Ormazd the god of the Arians helped, and also gods the tabifa-pa; thap appo. Hu inni arikka am, hiak inni tiras'karragat, others; for that I not wicked am, and not was a deceiver, hiak inni ...... yutta, hiak inni Hu, hiak inni Nimang-mi and not evil I have done, and not I, and not my family batar ukku yupogat; hiak inni Fabakra inni Is'rasa when(?) great became despotic; and not ? not ?
appattuikkimmas ........................................... Yoṣ-irra akka > Alyes Hu-nina
utterly
the man who family mine

šašinparrus-ta, yufri tartuka ir kuktì; ṣhiak Akka
had laboured, him in retribution him I favoured; and he who
afchova, ir-yufri Hu ir afpiya appattuikkimmas akkari ukga
injured (?), him I alew utterly every one ?
innI yutta.
not I did.

The many unknown words in this paragraph, and the mutilated condition both of the Persian and Scythic inscriptions, forbid any hopes of a successful analysis, without a better acquaintance with the Ugrian languages than I possess; a few guesses are set down, but without much confidence. Some further observations may be found in the vocabulary. The word baluikparrus-ta is not quite correctly given in the transcript, p. 59, but the first part is very uncertain. The additional words found at Colonel Rawlinson's second visit to Behistun have suggested the reading of the latter part; but there appears to be a bit in the version which was not in the original text.

IV. 14. hiak Tarišyavaus Ko nanri:—Ni, Ko, Akka vasišin
and Darius king says:—Thou, king, who hereafter
nikti, Yoṣ-irra titrasra yufri hini in-kannnti, hiak hini Akka
mayest be, the man a liar him do not befriend, and do not who
appatštuikkimmas yuttìs.
utterly (?).

The last clause is unintelligible to me, and the last word is defective; there is certainly some prohibitory clause at the end, which can hardly be equivalent to the Persian original.

IV. 15. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri:—Ni akka vasišin > Tipi
and Darius king says:—Thou who hereafter tablet
ye chiyainti appo Hu rilusa, ye innakkaniva, ...........
this seat which I have written, [and] these figures, do not
........ki rinti; thap innifapata yechitu kuktàs.
injury to them; as long as thou livest thus preserve.

The conjectural emendation proposed by Colonel Rawlinson, in the Notes, p. ix, is supported by ṣo: ṣo ve n; but I would suggest svatšd instead of svaiys one.
IV. 16. hiak anka — Tipi ye chiyain-ti, ye innakkaniwa,
and if tablet this thou seest,[and]these figures,
.........................rinti, thap innifapata chitu kuktainta, Auramasta
and doest no injury to them, as long as thou livest thus preservest, Ormazd
Ni iukanis-ni, hišak kutta Nimans-ni kitinti, hiak viallu
thee befriend thee, and also family thy be to thee, and very
taka rasti-ni, hiak kutta appo yutirti, yuvenpa Auramasta
long be thy life, and also what thou shalt do, that Ormazd
atgas-ni.
increase thee.

In these two paragraphs, as well as in the next, the Scythic words
signifying "doing injury" are mutilated, and singularly enough the
verbal termination rinti is all that remains in the three places. For
innifapata, see the Vocabulary. Chitu, in l. 86, is an obvious mis-
take for yechitu. Viallu taka rasti-ni is equivalent to viallu
iktaka takti-ni of l. 75. A comparison of dšanai with atšaiika,
"great," an epithet of "the world" in the Alwand Inscription (of
which Colonel Rawlinson took an impression that leaves no doubt of
the accuracy of the reading), inclines me to believe that this verb
must signify "enlarge," "extend," and the equivalent Persian term
danauteva will be allied to the Sanskrit tanu.* This explanation
will give a very probable meaning to the disputed duriya apiya,
occurring so often in the small inscriptions.

IV. 17. hišak anka — Tipi ye innakkaniwa ..........rinti, inul
and if tablet this [and] figures thou injurest, not
kukirti, Auramasta Nin aspis-ni, hiak kutta Nimans-ni
thou shalt preserve, Ormazd thee slay thee, and also family thy
hini kitinti, hiak appo yuttainti apin Auramasta rifapis-ni.
not be to thee, and what thou doest that Ormazd spoil for thee.

There is no equivalent here for the Persian utámaiya yává taumá
ahatiya, which in the preceding paragraph is represented by thap
innifapata. The word which I have made apin in l. 89, was very
probably Nin, as in the similar phrases in lines 76 and 88.

All the above paragraphs from the fourth inclusive, are, I confess,
but unsatisfactorily explained; but I believe the version upon the

* Some doubt may attach to this explanation, arising from the emendation in
Notes, p. x, where we find jadanauteva instead of danauteva.
whole is a step in advance. A larger acquaintance with the languages will do much, and I am persuaded that many letters, become invisible upon the paper casts, may be recovered by a closer examination of the rock. In the mean time, what is here given will aid future investigators, and enable a Finnish scholar to give a much better explanation than I could accomplish by the most protracted study.

IV. 18. hiak Tariyavaus Ko nanri: — Vinaparna yesi, and Darius king says:— Intaphernes named, Visparra Sakri, Parsar-ra; hiak Yuttana yesi, Tukkarra Sakri, Veisparas' son, a Persian; and Otanes named, Socres' son, Parsar-ra; hiak Gauparva yesi, Martuniya Sakri, Parsar-ra; hiak a Persian; and Gobryas named, Mardonius' son, a Persian; and Vitarna yesi, Bakapikna Sakri, Parsar-ra; hiak Bakapuksa yesi, Hydarnes named, Megabignes' son, a Persian; and Megabyzus named, Tattuvanuya Sakri, Parsar-ra; hiak Artumannis, Vaukka Sakri, Zopyrus (?) son, a Persian; and Ardamanes, Vahuka's son, Parsar-ra; appi Yoš Hu tayufa, kus Hu Gaumaṭṭa akka a Persian; these men me accompanied, while I Gomates the Makus afpiya, akka nanri, Hu Bartiya tar kuras-na; hiak avasir Magian killed, who said, I [am] Bardes, son of Cyrus; and as Yoš Appi Hu tahuvanluṭfa, Ni, Ko, akka vasissin nikli ……………… men these me aided, thou king who hereafter may be, remember appo Yoš appir kuktās.

It appears that the usual yesi was left out after the name of Ardamanes in l. 92, unless the name was written merely Artuvan; there would then be space for it. The word afpiya is restored after Makus in l. 93, though I should have expected yufri there; but the verb is wanted somewhere, and no other place appears at all suited for it: after kus some word ending in gut is generally found, but I know not what to put; perhaps afpigat; but there is no authority for it. The intent of the closing sentence is, no doubt, to call on the successors of the king to confer favours on the descendants of the men who assisted Darius in raising himself to the throne of Persia; it appears from Colonel Rawlinson's Notes, p. xviii., that this was contained in another paragraph, which was composed of two or three additional lines, but they are lost with the exception of a few letters; the Scythic version appears to have closed as above given. There was no room on the m for
Detached Inscriptions.
